comments.text:
The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, the Armenian 
Massacres and, traditionally by Armenians, as Medz Yeghern was the Ottoman 
government's systematic extermination of its minority Armenian subjects 
from their historic homeland within the territory constituting the 
present-day Republic of Turkey. The total number of people killed as a 
result has been estimated at between 1 and 1.5 million. The starting date 
is conventionally held to be 24 April 1915, the day Ottoman authorities 
rounded up and arrested some 250 Armenian intellectuals and community 
leaders in Constantinople. The genocide was carried out during and after 
World War I and implemented in two phases: the wholesale killing of the 
able-bodied male population through massacre and subjection of army 
conscripts to forced labor, followed by the deportation of women, children, 
the elderly and infirm on death marches leading to the Syrian desert. 
Driven forward by military escorts, the deportees were deprived of food and 
water and subjected to periodic robbery, rape, and massacre. Other 
indigenous and Christian ethnic groups such as the Assyrians and the 
Ottoman Greeks were similarly targeted for extermination by the Ottoman 
government, and their treatment is considered by many historians to be part 
of the same genocidal policy. The majority of Armenian diaspora communities 
around the world came into being as a direct result of the genocide.
comments.author: Leijona totuus

comments.author: Christopher Tyler

comments.text:
+That Guy Then what you are telling me is that we torture our own troops? 
 Because, for one, any prisoner of the United States, with even half a 
brain, absolutely knows that the U.S. is not going to do anything to them 
that is of any major, life changing significance.  That's more true now, 
than ever, inasmuch as our esteemed President has shared our playbook with 
the world.  But, even before that, everyone knew what America would and 
would not do, with the worse that could happen is being sent off to a black 
site in another country where that country might get physical with you, but 
not permanently damage.  

Moreover, the definition of torture is very wide ranging and under our laws 
and water-boarding  was found to be lawful when it was used and the 
psychologist who put together the program has also said that it was highly 
effective.  t.  Hell, people also find depriving people of sleep and loud 
noise to be torture.  And, of course, as a general rule, no one wants to be 
barbaric and REALLY torture anyone.  However, when you have intelligence 
reports coming in as to potential suitcase Nuke attacks, water-boarding for 
intelligence hardly seems excessive.   Also, far more people, than not, 
would think water-boarding is a more than tame exercise if they had a 
prisoner who knew the whereabouts of their family who was going to be 
killed if said person didn't talk.
comments.author: Christopher Tyler

comments.text:
+Christopher Tyler Comparing VOLUNTARY water-boarding as a part of training 
to INVOLUNTARY water-boarding as a means to extract information is beyond 
apples and oranges, it's apples and mustard gas.
